trans-unit.source: Create, start, or delete an Application Gateway | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Create, start, or delete an Application Gateway | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Create, configure, start, and delete an Azure Application Gateway
trans-unit.target: Create, configure, start, and delete an Azure Application Gateway

trans-unit.source: Create, start, or delete an Application Gateway
trans-unit.target: Create, start, or delete an Application Gateway

trans-unit.source: In this release, you can create an Application Gateway by using PowerShell or REST API calls.
trans-unit.target: In this release, you can create an Application Gateway by using PowerShell or REST API calls.

trans-unit.source: Azure portal and CLI support will be provided in an upcoming release.
trans-unit.target: Azure portal and CLI support will be provided in an upcoming release.

trans-unit.source: This article walks you through the steps to create and configure, start, and delete an Application Gateway.
trans-unit.target: This article walks you through the steps to create and configure, start, and delete an Application Gateway.

trans-unit.source: Before you begin
trans-unit.target: Before you begin

trans-unit.source: Install the latest version of the Azure PowerShell cmdlets using the Web Platform Installer.
trans-unit.target: Install the latest version of the Azure PowerShell cmdlets using the Web Platform Installer.

trans-unit.source: You can download and install the latest version from the Windows PowerShell section of the Download page.
trans-unit.target: You can download and install the latest version from the Windows PowerShell section of the Download page.

trans-unit.source: Verify that you have a working virtual network with a valid subnet.
trans-unit.target: Verify that you have a working virtual network with a valid subnet.

trans-unit.source: Verify that you have backend servers either in the virtual network, or with an assigned public IP/VIP.
trans-unit.target: Verify that you have backend servers either in the virtual network, or with an assigned public IP/VIP.

trans-unit.source: To create a new Application Gateway, perform the following steps in the order listed.
trans-unit.target: To create a new Application Gateway, perform the following steps in the order listed.

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Create a new Application Gateway</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Create a new Application Gateway</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Configure the gateway</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Configure the gateway</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Set the gateway configuration</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Set the gateway configuration</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Start the gateway</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Start the gateway</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Verify the gateway status</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Verify the gateway status</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: If you want to delete an Application Gateway, see <link><linkText>Delete an Application Gateway</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you want to delete an Application Gateway, see <link><linkText>Delete an Application Gateway</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Create a new Application Gateway
trans-unit.target: Create a new Application Gateway

trans-unit.source: To create the gateway, use the New-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet, replacing the values with your own.
trans-unit.target: To create the gateway, use the New-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet, replacing the values with your own.

trans-unit.source: Note that billing for the gateway does not start at this point.
trans-unit.target: Note that billing for the gateway does not start at this point.

trans-unit.source: Billing begins in a later step, when the gateway is successfully started.
trans-unit.target: Billing begins in a later step, when the gateway is successfully started.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows the cmdlet on the first line followed by the output.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows the cmdlet on the first line followed by the output.

trans-unit.source: To validate that the gateway was created, you can use the Get-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To validate that the gateway was created, you can use the Get-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: In the sample, Description, InstanceCount, and GatewaySize are optional parameters.
trans-unit.target: In the sample, Description, InstanceCount, and GatewaySize are optional parameters.

trans-unit.source: The default value for InstanceCount is 2, with a maximum value of 10.
trans-unit.target: The default value for InstanceCount is 2, with a maximum value of 10.

trans-unit.source: The default value for GatewaySize is Medium.
trans-unit.target: The default value for GatewaySize is Medium.

trans-unit.source: Small and Large are other available values.
trans-unit.target: Small and Large are other available values.

trans-unit.source: Vip and DnsName are shown as blank because the gateway has not started yet.
trans-unit.target: Vip and DnsName are shown as blank because the gateway has not started yet.

trans-unit.source: These will be created once the gateway is in the running state.
trans-unit.target: These will be created once the gateway is in the running state.

trans-unit.source: Configure the gateway
trans-unit.target: Configure the gateway

trans-unit.source: An Application Gateway configuration consists of multiple values.
trans-unit.target: An Application Gateway configuration consists of multiple values.

trans-unit.source: The values can be tied together to construct the configuration.
trans-unit.target: The values can be tied together to construct the configuration.

trans-unit.source: The values are:
trans-unit.target: The values are:

trans-unit.source: Backend server pool: The list of IP addresses of the backend servers.
trans-unit.target: Backend server pool: The list of IP addresses of the backend servers.

trans-unit.source: The IP addresses listed should either belong to the VNet subnet, or should be a public IP/VIP.
trans-unit.target: The IP addresses listed should either belong to the VNet subnet, or should be a public IP/VIP.

trans-unit.source: Backend server pool settings: Every pool has settings like port, protocol, and cookie-based affinity.
trans-unit.target: Backend server pool settings: Every pool has settings like port, protocol, and cookie-based affinity.

trans-unit.source: These settings are tied to a pool and are applied to all servers within the pool.
trans-unit.target: These settings are tied to a pool and are applied to all servers within the pool.

trans-unit.source: Frontend Port: This port is the public port opened on the Application Gateway.
trans-unit.target: Frontend Port: This port is the public port opened on the Application Gateway.

trans-unit.source: Traffic hits this port, and then gets redirected to one of the backend servers.
trans-unit.target: Traffic hits this port, and then gets redirected to one of the backend servers.

trans-unit.source: Listener: The listener has a front end port, a protocol (Http or Https, these are case-sensitive), and the SSL certificate name (if configuring SSL offload).
trans-unit.target: Listener: The listener has a front end port, a protocol (Http or Https, these are case-sensitive), and the SSL certificate name (if configuring SSL offload).

trans-unit.source: Rule: The rule binds the listener and the backend server pool, and defines which backend server pool the traffic should be directed to when it hits a particular listener.
trans-unit.target: Rule: The rule binds the listener and the backend server pool, and defines which backend server pool the traffic should be directed to when it hits a particular listener.

trans-unit.source: Currently, only the basic rule is supported.
trans-unit.target: Currently, only the basic rule is supported.

trans-unit.source: The basic rule is round-robin load distribution.
trans-unit.target: The basic rule is round-robin load distribution.

trans-unit.source: You can construct your configuration either by creating a configuration object, or by using a configuration XML file.
trans-unit.target: You can construct your configuration either by creating a configuration object, or by using a configuration XML file.

trans-unit.source: To construct your configuration by using a configuration XML file, use the following sample.
trans-unit.target: To construct your configuration by using a configuration XML file, use the following sample.

trans-unit.source: Configuration XML sample
trans-unit.target: Configuration XML sample

trans-unit.source: Set the gateway configuration
trans-unit.target: Set the gateway configuration

trans-unit.source: Next, you'll set the Application Gateway.
trans-unit.target: Next, you'll set the Application Gateway.

trans-unit.source: You can use the Set-AzureApplicationGatewayConfig cmdlet with a configuration object, or with a configuration XML file.
trans-unit.target: You can use the Set-AzureApplicationGatewayConfig cmdlet with a configuration object, or with a configuration XML file.

trans-unit.source: Start the gateway
trans-unit.target: Start the gateway

trans-unit.source: Once the gateway has been configured, use the Start-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet to start the gateway.
trans-unit.target: Once the gateway has been configured, use the Start-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet to start the gateway.

trans-unit.source: Billing for an Application Gateway begins after the gateway has been successfully started.
trans-unit.target: Billing for an Application Gateway begins after the gateway has been successfully started.

trans-unit.source: The Start-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet might take up to 15-20 minutes to complete.
trans-unit.target: The Start-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet might take up to 15-20 minutes to complete.

trans-unit.source: Verify the gateway status
trans-unit.target: Verify the gateway status

trans-unit.source: Use the Get-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet to check the status of the gateway.
trans-unit.target: Use the Get-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet to check the status of the gateway.

trans-unit.source: If Start-AzureApplicationGateway succeeded in the previous step, the State should be Running, and the Vip and DnsName should have valid entries.
trans-unit.target: If Start-AzureApplicationGateway succeeded in the previous step, the State should be Running, and the Vip and DnsName should have valid entries.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows an Application Gateway that is up, running, and ready to take traffic destined to http://.cloudapp.net.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows an Application Gateway that is up, running, and ready to take traffic destined to http://.cloudapp.net.

trans-unit.source: Delete an Application Gateway
trans-unit.target: Delete an Application Gateway

trans-unit.source: To delete an Application Gateway:
trans-unit.target: To delete an Application Gateway:

trans-unit.source: Use the Stop-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet to stop the gateway.
trans-unit.target: Use the Stop-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet to stop the gateway.

trans-unit.source: Use the Remove-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet to remove the gateway.
trans-unit.target: Use the Remove-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet to remove the gateway.

trans-unit.source: Verify the gateway has been removed by using the Get-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: Verify the gateway has been removed by using the Get-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows the Stop-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet on the first line, followed by the output.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows the Stop-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet on the first line, followed by the output.

trans-unit.source: Once the Application Gateway is in a Stopped state, use the Remove-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet to remove the service.
trans-unit.target: Once the Application Gateway is in a Stopped state, use the Remove-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet to remove the service.

trans-unit.source: To verify that the service has been removed, you can use the Get-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To verify that the service has been removed, you can use the Get-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: This step is not required.
trans-unit.target: This step is not required.

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: If you want to configure SSL offload, see <link><linkText>Configure Application Gateway for SSL offload</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you want to configure SSL offload, see <link><linkText>Configure Application Gateway for SSL offload</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: If you want to configure an Application Gateway to use with ILB, see <link><linkText>Create an Application Gateway with an Internal Load Balancer (ILB)</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you want to configure an Application Gateway to use with ILB, see <link><linkText>Create an Application Gateway with an Internal Load Balancer (ILB)</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: If you want more information about load balancing options in general, see:
trans-unit.target: If you want more information about load balancing options in general, see:

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Azure Load Balancer</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Azure Load Balancer</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Azure Traffic Manager</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Azure Traffic Manager</linkText><title></title></link>
